_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for Prairie State Generating Company (PSGC) located at 1739 New Marigold Road, Marissa, Illinois.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:

PSGC is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. Our comprehensive program designed to protect workers from industrial hazards demonstrates this commitment.  Engineering controls are in place to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  

PSGC has a rigorous safety training program covering potential health & safety hazards and safe workplace procedures designed to eliminate or minimize hazards.  Therefore, allowing employees to work in a safe work environment. 

PSGC is a non-responding facility and relies on contracted service providers to respond to chemical releases.

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:

PSGC maintains one substance, anhydrous ammonia, on site in amounts exceeding the Risk Management Program (RMP) threshold quantity. Anhydrous ammonia is used in the selective catalytic reduction air pollution control devices installed on two utility boilers.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:

PSGC has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]

PSGC maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis [40 CFR

Part 68.67]

Comprehensive analyses ensure that hazards associated with PSGC processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  PSGC's process hazard assessment uses a HAZOP/checklist-type analysis for the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PHAs are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]

To ensure safe operations, PSGC maintains detailed written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation, such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]

PSGC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are to ensure that employees operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every 3 years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]

PSGC carries out documented checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. PSGCs mechanical integrity inspection program follows RAGAGEP for prescribing nondestructive examinations of the entire system regularly. Inspected process equipment includes pressure vessels, piping systems, pressure relief systems, and system controls. Maintenance activities are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Any equipment deficiencies identified are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change [MOC] [40 CFR Part 68.75]

Written Management of Change procedures are in place at PSGC to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and operational procedures. Facility opera

tors or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to address any changes.

Pre-Startup Safety Review [PSSR] [40 CFR Part 68.77]

Pre-start-up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to existing processes are conducted routinely at PSGC.  These reviews confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup before placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79]

PSGC conducts audits regularly to determine whether the provisions set out under the US EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required due to the audits are undertaken promptly.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]

PSGC promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident and any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. 

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]

PSGC believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, PSGC employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information resulting from Process Hazard Analyses.

Hot Work Permit [40 CFR Part 68.85]

PSGC has a hot work process that includes issuing a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process. 

Contractor Safety Program [40 CFR Part 68.87] 

PSGC hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. A thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out before sel

ecting a contractor.  PSGC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards associated with the contractor's work and the corresponding processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.

The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:

PSGC has had no ammonia releases reportable under the five-year accident history.  

The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:

In the event of an incident, PSGC has systems in place to respond quickly. The process can be shut down on an emergency basis. The facility has an evacuation plan, adequate on-site first aid, medical treatment and notification of local emergency response agencies. PSGC is a non-responding facility and relies on contracted service providers to respond to chemical releases.  The facility emergency action plan is reviewed with contracted service providers on a regular basis.

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:

Prairie State has a Management of Change policy to govern safety improvements to equipment and work practices involving anhydrous ammonia. The policy requires employee stakeholders to periodically review and revise the Risk Management Plan, the physical anhydrous ammonia system, and operation and maintenance procedures.
